awd_abstract_narration:
Moduli theory concerns itself with understanding all possible shapes the space can have. For example, if one takes a rectangle and identifies opposite edges, one obtains a cylinder, and further identifying the remaining edges gives what mathematicians call a torus - the surface of a donut. Starting with rectangles of different shapes one ends up with different tori. Furthermore, one can also do similar identifications starting with parallelograms, to get more tori. It can be proven that the such tori are intrinsically different - if one lives on the surface of a torus and cannot see the whole surface from far away, one can still distinguish the kind of parallelogram that was used to build the torus. The moduli space of tori is then the set of all possible shapes of tori that are intrinsically different. Amazingly enough this "set of shapes" itself is a nice geometric object. This project deals with posing problems of similar type: of classifying some geometric objects, together with some further information on them, and of studying the resulting moduli spaces.

The project aims to understand better the geometry of various compact moduli spaces. Together with various collaborators, the PI will construct a modular compactification of the moduli space of complex curves together with a differential with prescribed multiplicities of zeroes, compactifying the so-called strata - phase spaces in Teichmuller dynamics. Real-normalized meromorphic differentials will be applied to bound the number of cusps of plane curves of a given degree. The project also will investigate the birational geometry and homology of various compactifications of the moduli spaces of cubic threefolds. Lastly the project will continue the investigations on homology and higher dimensional cycles on moduli spaces of abelian varieties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI's work is in moduli theory: the study of possible shapes of objects of a given type. For example, one can consider all possible shapes of parallelograms, up to rescaling the size of all their sides, or - when gluing the opposite sides - think of this as the space of shapes of donuts (mathematically, called tori). This example is the moduli space of elliptic curves, also known as genus one Riemann surfaces. In general, much of the PI's work revolved around studying the geometry of the moduli space of higher genus Riemann surfaces - imagine donuts with more holes or handles attached, eg pretzels.

Together with his collaborators, the PI constructed a smooth functorial compactification of the moduli space of Riemann surfaces together with a differential. By a differential here one means the choice of a local (complex-number-valued) coordinate at every point of the surface, such thgat this coordinate is well-defined up to translating the complex plane, at all but finitely many points of the Riemann surface. By a compactification one means studying what happens when the Riemann surface degenerates, i.e. when one pinches some curve(s) drawn on this Riemann surface, and functorial means that one considers the Riemann surfaces with a differential, and degenerate (pinched) Riemann surfaces together with some kind of a data of a degenerate differential.

The constructed compactification is smooth, which is to say can be described by usual Euclidean coordinates near every of its points. This compactification is of an algebro-geometric nature, but should have applications in Teichmuller dynamics, which is a field that in particular studies the properties of billiards played on polygonal tables.

Additionally, the PI studied moduli of cubic surfaces and threefolds, and other questions in classification of varieties.
